prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold,
The world grows quiet, slow and old.
Tea steams in trembling porcelain hands,
Blankets gather in gentle bands.

My thoughts drift soft as falling snow,
Outside the window’s distant glow.
The body aches, the spirit sighs,
Yet in this hush, a small hope lies.

Each cough a gentle timekeeper’s chime,
Marking the hours, passing time.
The taste of lemon, honey’s gold—
Simple comforts, stories told.

Now when I have a cold, I find
The world, for once, is soft and kind.
And resting here, apart, alone,
I meet a peace I’ve never known.

Now when I have a cold,
My bones ring hollow, stories untold.
The world, muffled, turns to grey,
Blankets swallow the light of day.

A cup of tea, steam rising slow,
Echoes of laughter I used to know.
My voice is a whisper, lost in the air,
Dreams flicker softly, floating somewhere.

The hours drip down like honey, thick,
Each moment heavy, every breath quick.
Yet in this stillness, I find a song,
A comfort in weakness, where I belong.

Now when I have a cold, I see
Gentle patience, time to just be.
The hush of illness, bittersweet gold,
A reminder to rest, to heal, to hold.

Now when I have a cold,
The day folds in, the sun turns gold.
I wrap myself in woven fleece,
And let my busy thoughts release.

A kettle hums a gentle tune,
My window frames a silver moon.
Outside, the world goes rushing by,
Inside, I dream and softly sigh.

Each sneeze a punctuation mark,
In sentences of quiet dark.
My nose is red, my eyelids heavy,
Yet in this pause, I feel less weary.

Now when I have a cold, I learn
To let the fevered moments burn.
And in this forced and tender rest,
I find small ways to feel my best.

Now when I have a cold,
Even sunlight feels too bold.
I burrow deep beneath my sheet,
Listening to my heartbeat.

The world outside continues on,
But my room is dusk and dawn.
A mug of soup, a gentle hand,
A tissue box within close stand.

I watch the raindrops on the glass,
Measuring hours as they pass.
My voice is hoarse, my head is light,
Yet comfort dwells in this respite.

Now when I have a cold, I slow,
And let the quiet moments grow.
A blessing, hidden in the ache,
A reason, softly, to awake.

Now when I have a cold,
The world outside is harsh and cold.
I sip warm tea and close my eyes,
While fevered dreams begin to rise.

Each breath is thick, each movement slow,
A gentle ache in ebb and flow.
The hush of blankets, dim-lit room,
Becomes a tender kind of womb.

I listen to the storm outside,
While under covers, safe, I hide.
The world grows distant, time stands still,
As rest becomes my only will.

Now when I have a cold, I find
A softer world within my mind.
And when at last the fever breaks,
A gentler me, anew, awakes.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept silent-footed past my tender dreams?
Each hour unspools the golden thread of truth,
And hastens daylight’s sun to shadow’s seams.

I grasp at moments, bright as fleeting dew,
Yet find them vanished, scattered in his wake.
The mirror’s glass reveals a self I knew,
Now etched by journeys I did not forsake.

O gentle thief, why must you press so near?
Why must your touch turn blush to sober grey?
Yet in your stealing, wisdom may appear—
A gift within the losses of each day.

So let me meet you, Time, with open eyes,
And treasure youth, not mourn how swiftly flies.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With silent fingers plucks the morning rose,
Its petals fading, wilting in the truth
That all must yield to what the old one knows.

He weaves his silver through each raven thread,
And carves fine lines upon the eager brow;
He steals the song that once my spirit led,
And leaves me wondering, quietly, now.

Yet in his wake, a gentler grace he leaves:
A deeper laughter, memories distilled;
For though he takes, he also softly weaves
A wisdom that the restless heart has stilled.

Oh, subtle thief, though youth you may consume,
You grant the soul new gardens yet to bloom.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Disguised in laughter, shadows, whispered sighs.
He tiptoes by, and with a deft untruth,
Turns spring to summer, day to starless skies.

I chase his footprints through the morning light,
Remembering the days when all was new;
But hours slip quietly into the night,
And dreams once bright now wear a softer hue.

Yet, in his theft, Time grants a gentle grace,
A mellow sweetness ripened by the years.
What once was lost, another joy may place,
And wisdom rises gently from our fears.

So let me greet each moment as it flies,
And thank the thief for all that he belies.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unraveled innocence with gentle hands,
His quiet larceny conceals the truth
Of fleeting moments slipping through life’s sands.

A glance, a laugh, a promise made in spring—
All gathered in his ever-hungry chest.
He leaves behind the wisdom years can bring,
Yet steals the blush and vigor from the rest.

Still, in his wake, a calm acceptance grows;
The heart expands to welcome every scar.
The beauty Time bestows, the soul well knows:
A map of journeys traveled near and far.

So let us raise a glass to all that’s gone,
And cherish what remains, from dusk to dawn.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unspooled the golden thread from days gone by?
He steals in silence, bearing off the truth
That once I danced beneath an endless sky.

He whispers gently at the window pane,
With silvered breath and footsteps soft as light,
Unnoticed, leaves a trace of gentle pain,
A shadow where there once was fierce delight.

Yet, Time, for all you pilfer from my years,
You gift me wisdom, memories to keep,
A deeper laughter echoing through tears,
And dreams that bloom while waking and asleep.

So take my youth, and trade for something more:
A soul that’s rich in love and tales of yore.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With gentle hands and silent, measured pace,
Unraveled dreams, and blunted edges smooth,
The hopeful brightness fading from my face.

He tiptoes in upon the midnight air,
His footsteps lost amid the ticking years,
Stealing the golden strands from every hair,
And changing laughter’s echo into tears.

Yet in his wake, not all is stolen, lost—
He leaves the wisdom earned by living long,
The mellowed sweetness bought at bitter cost,
The gentle courage born of being strong.

So though he steals, he also gifts anew:
A deeper love, a clearer, kinder view.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Who steals away the morning’s golden fire,
And leaves in place the sober shade of truth
That tempers every hope and bright desire.

He moves unseen, a shadow on the wall,
A gentle hush upon the eager heart,
And as the days in steady silence fall,
He weaves his artful web, each thread a part.

Yet in his theft, he grants a gift as well:
A memory burnished, sweeter for the pain,
A wisdom rising where the wild dreams fell,
A softer sunlight shining through the rain.

So let him come, for though he takes the rose,
He leaves behind the fragrance as it goes.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whose silent fingers trace the lines of age,
Unspooling dreams once bright with hope and truth,
And turning fresh beginnings to the page.

He steals not roughly, but with gentle care,
A petal fallen softly from the rose,
And in the mirror’s glass, I see him there,
A quiet guest whose presence no one knows.

Yet though he takes, he leaves a gift behind:
A deepened gaze, a knowing in the eyes,
The patience that a restless soul might find,
And strength that in the heart of sorrow lies.

So let me greet this thief with open arms,
For what he steals, he leaves in subtler charms.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Who gently slips the color from the dawn,
And in his wake, leaves only silent truth,
A quiet hush where vibrant dreams have gone.

His shadow falls upon the laughter bright,
And softens voices once so quick with song;
He dims the stars that glittered in the night,
And teaches hearts where they may now belong.

Yet though he takes, he gives a wisdom rare,
A patient grace, a kindness deep and true;
For in the ashes hope can still repair,
And every ending births a world anew.

So let me thank the thief for all he’s done:
For every loss, some deeper life’s begun.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Who tiptoes through the corridors of years,
His gentle larceny, a silent truth,
Extracting laughter, leaving softer tears.

He gathers petals from the bloom of spring,
And tucks away the sunlight from our eyes,
Yet in the autumn’s hush, we learn to sing
Of beauty found in what the old age buys.

Though fleeting days may vanish as they pass,
And mirrors show the footprints on our skin,
Time’s theft reveals the gold beneath the brass—
A wisdom earned, a peace that dwells within.

So let him come, that silent, subtle thief,
For in his taking, there is sweet relief.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
God is the refuge of his saints,
A haven when the tempest breaks,
A gentle hand when courage faints,
A light when every shadow aches.

Within His arms the weary rest,
He gathers all who stumble, fall;
He hears each trembling, whispered quest,
And answers with a loving call.

No storm can tear the soul apart
That leans upon His boundless grace;
He mends the wounds of every heart,
And shelters in His holy place.

Though earth may fail and shadows loom,
Though hope may flicker, faint, and pale,
His presence fills the darkest room—
His faithfulness will never fail.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Their stronghold through the years unknown;
Forever faithful, never faint,
He claims each trusting heart His own.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the wildest storm,
A gentle voice that soothes complaints,
A faithful hand that keeps them warm.

When shadows fall and doubts arise,
His promises are strong and true;
He lifts His children to the skies,
Their courage born each day anew.

Though trials press on every side,
And fears would claim the trembling soul,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

Steadying, mending every part.

But for now, she craves the peace inside—
Sometimes, she wants nothing but to hide.

Beneath the gentle hush of dusk’s soft veil,

She drifts through days with laughter well-rehearsed,

But in the quiet, dreams begin to stir—

She gathers strength, her vision not a blur,

Where echoes fade and burdens slide,

So she tucks herself away from light,
And lets the noise drift far away.

In the shelter of her solitude,

And though she hides, she still renews—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

responses.text:
A poet loses his power for poetry—  
The well runs dry beneath a silent sky.  
Words, once stars, now flicker and fade,  
Their music gone, their magic unmade.  

He sits with pen trembling in his hand,  
Echoes of verses, castles of sand.  
The rhythms falter, metaphors break,  
Dreams once so vivid now fail to wake.  

Yet in this hush, a strange peace grows:  
The poet, emptied, quietly knows  
That silence, too, may cradle the soul—  
Even shadows can render us whole.

A poet loses his power for poetry,  
His tongue, once silver, rusts in the rain.  
Ink stains his fingers, cold and empty,  
Lines collapse into silence, a formless pain.  

He gazes out, searching for the seasons  
That blossomed once in the orchard of his mind—  
Now barren branches, no reason  
To hope the spring will ever unwind.  

But in the hush, beneath the sorrow,  
A seed of longing takes root and grows.  
Perhaps tomorrow, or some tomorrow,  
He’ll find his voice where the wild wind blows.

A poet loses his power for poetry;  
The ink dries up, the muses turn away.  
The world once painted with words and light  
Is now a pale, unyielding gray.  

He listens for the song that filled his veins,  
But all he hears is silence, cold and deep.  
He searches for the fire, but only remains  
Are ashes of dreams he cannot keep.  

Yet in the quiet, where verses once grew,  
He learns to see with humbler eyes—  
That even when the language is through,  
The heart remembers how to rise.

A poet loses his power for poetry—  
His voice, a hollow shell in the wind.  
No gilded words to dress the world,  
No verses left to transcend.  

He walks among memories, faded and thin,  
Grasping for lines that never begin.  
Yet in the silence, some truth appears:  
A life lived quietly, honest and clear.  

For sometimes a hush is the poet’s refrain,  
A pause in the storm, a break in the chain.  
And perhaps in the space where the poems depart,  
He’ll find the poem that lives in his heart.

A poet loses his power for poetry—  
The lines grow distant, the images blur.  
Once, every breath could conjure a sea,  
Now, only silence answers her.  

She stares at the page, unbroken and white,  
Recalling old music, the rhythm of light.  
But the words have retreated, the metaphors hide,  
Leaving her empty, longing inside.  

Yet sometimes a drought is a gift in disguise;  
The heart replenishes, the soul grows wise.  
A poet, though silent, is still a poet—  
The song will return when she’s ready to know it.

His pen lies idle, a relic on the page.

No more do words assemble in sweet rows,

He walks the garden, hears the wind’s refrain,

Yet in absence, he tastes a different pain:
The quiet sadness he cannot dispel.

Perhaps, in this silence, a seed will grow—
A new kind of poetry only loss can show.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
The lines that once leapt, tumble, unformed.
His mind’s garden, once bursting in bloom,
Now parched, the petals wilted and warmed.

He listens for music in syllables’ fall,
But silence, thick as fog, muffles each beat.
No images visit, no metaphors call,
The rhythm of longing stumbles in defeat.

Yet, perhaps in the quiet, the emptiness grows
A new kind of wisdom, a hush in his chest.
For sometimes a pause is the poem that shows
How loss, too, can speak, and be blessed.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
Yet in that loss, another truth may be.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
His hands, once nimble with rhyme, now tremble.
The pages stare back, blank and unbroken,
A sea of white where words once assembled.

He recalls the rush of inspiration’s light,

Now, he wanders shadows in the night,

But absence, too, can be a song,
A silent lyric in the heart’s deep well.
For in losing the voice that carried him along,
He learns what it means to dwell.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
Yet finds, in silence, a subtle poetry.

A poet loses his power for poetry—

Ideas, once bold, now flee quietly,

He searches the dusk for a flicker of thought,

But the wellspring is barren, the muse overwrought,
Imagination lost in a haze.

He sits with his silence, uneasy and raw,
A stranger in lands he once knew.
Yet maybe in stillness, he’s learning to draw
A poem from absence too.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
Yet in that void, something else may break through.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'

responses.text:
There is a law which guarantees
That every sun must someday set,
That every wave upon the sea
Returns to where the shore is wet.

There is a rule beneath the sky
That binds the seed to root and rise,
A secret code in every sigh,
A promise written in our eyes.

Though time may wind and seasons change,
And fortune's wheel may turn or freeze,
Still hearts endure, though rearranged—
There is a law which guarantees.

So let us trust what we can't see,
The patient thread within the loom;
For what must be, at last, shall be,
And hope will blossom, given room.

There is a law which guarantees
A dawn for every night,
A balm for every ache we seize,
A spark in darkest blight.

It whispers through the silent halls
Where longing dares to roam;
It paints the cracks upon the walls,
And calls the wanderer home.

Unwritten, yet it binds the stars,
It hums in falling leaves;
It seals the wounds of ancient wars,
And soothes the soul that grieves.

There is a law which guarantees
That life will rise anew,
That from the dust, on gentle breeze,
Will drift hope’s silver hue.

There is a law which guarantees
The river’s bend and mountain’s knees,
The turning leaf, the falling rain,
The healing after every pain.

Invisible, but always near,
It sings within what we hold dear,
A promise woven through the days,
A hand that guides us through the haze.

For though we stumble, though we fear,
Some force unseen will draw us near
To morning’s light, to open skies—
A truth that under sorrow lies.

There is a law which guarantees
That hope will root in memories,
And in the silence, softly grows
The courage only living knows.

There is a law which guarantees
The rising arc of days to come;
A silent pact the world agrees,
Inscribed on wind and beating drum.

It does not rest on written page,
Nor bow to courts or ink or seal,
But hums beneath the surface rage,
A current only time reveals.

It promises the frost will yield,
That wounds will heal, that hearts will mend;
A quiet justice, gently sealed,
That every journey finds its end.

There is a law which guarantees,
No matter loss or love or strife,
The universe will find its ease—
A balance at the heart of life.

There is a law which guarantees
That all things change, that nothing stays,
That time will carry memories
Like leaves adrift on autumn days.

It’s written not in statute books,
But whispered in the restless breeze,
In river stones and mountain brooks,
In silent, ancient guarantees.

This law assures the fading night
Will always yield to morning’s gold;
That sorrow’s weight, though never light,
Will loosen, slowly, from its hold.

There is a law which guarantees
That after loss, there comes release—
A gentle, certain, quiet peace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

As twilight settled in,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:
That's my window. This minute—
A frame of trembling light,
Where dusk and day entwine their hands
And whisper to the night.

The glass holds fleeting shadows,
Reflections of the past,
While future moments hover,
Uncertain, never cast.

A leaf shivers on the sill,
A secret wind slips through,
I press my palm against the pane,
And breathe the world anew.

This minute, brief and burning,
Belongs to only me:
A silent, golden threshold,
Between what was and will be.

That's my window. This minute.
Sun slants in, gold and thin,
Lacing the dust with memories.
I watch the world drift—
A child’s laughter, a car’s hush,
A bird’s sudden flight.

Time presses close, breath held,
As if the glass itself remembers
Every face, every storm, every wish
Cast into the morning air.

This minute is mine:
A hush, a spark, a fleeting glance—
The world softens at the edges,
Caught in the frame of now,
Before it slips away.

That's my window. This minute.
The world presses its cheek to the glass,
A hush of rain, a hush of thought,
Stilled in the trembling pass.

Outside, the streetlights flicker—
Amber in the rising gloom.
Inside, I cradle silence,
A small and sacred room.

Time slips thin as shadow
Across the pane's soft skin.
My breath fogs the boundary,
Lets hope and longing in.

This minute, I am watching—
The world’s quiet ballet,
Framed by my window, this minute,
Before it folds away.

That's my window. This minute—
Clouds drift by with lazy intent,
Shadows ripple across the floor,
A bird lands, quick and hesitant.

The glass is cool, my fingers trace
Patterns of raindrops and light,
Each second a hush, a promise,
Held in the silver twilight.

I gather the world in silence,
A witness to hush and flow,
This minute, this window, my anchor,
While seasons outside me go.

Time is a breath on the glass,
A whisper I almost hear,
That's my window. This minute—
The universe pauses here.

That's my window. This minute—
Where light and longing meet,
I watch the world unravel,
Beneath the city’s feet.

A crow perches on the gutter,
Clouds drift in silent streams,
The room behind me flickers
With the echo of old dreams.

I rest my head against the pane,
Count heartbeats with the rain,
Each moment fleeting, delicate,
A whisper I cannot contain.

That's my window. This minute—
My eyes hold the world at bay,
Gathering the hush and wonder
Before it slips away.

A tapestry of caring, each thread remakes

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

responses.text:
Let the night sleep, hush now, gentle world,
Drift with the silence, let darkness unfurl.
The stars are but watchers in velvet embrace,
Softly they glitter on time’s patient face.

Let the night sleep, don’t trouble the calm,
Let dreams be your refuge, the moon be your balm.
The worries of daylight, let them be gone,
Wrapped in the quiet, till new hope is drawn.

Let the night sleep, and cradle your mind,
In shadows and stillness, some solace you’ll find.
For even the restless must pause and retreat—
Let the night sleep, let your heart gently beat.

Let the night sleep, untroubled and deep,
A gentle blanket over the world it will keep.
The hush of the shadows, the lull of the breeze,
Whispering comfort to rivers and trees.

Leave worries behind, set your burdens aside,
Let dreams be the current on which you may ride.
Tomorrow will come with its own busy light,
But now let the darkness be quiet and right.

Let the night sleep, as you close your eyes,
Trust in the silence that underlies.
For peace is a gift the darkness will bring,
Let the night sleep—and let your soul sing.

Let the night sleep, do not wake the hush,
Let the silver moon bathe the world in its blush.
Soft are the hours when the city is still,
Dreams wander quiet, by their own gentle will.

Let the night sleep, let the darkness breathe in,
Restless hearts calm, let new hope begin.
Clouds drift like thoughts through the cool midnight air,
Peace settles softly, dissolving all care.

Let the night sleep, let the stars keep their guard,
Let shadows grow long in the cool, empty yard.
For morning will come with its bright, busy sweep—
But now, let the night, just for once, truly sleep.

Let the night sleep, fold its wings around you,
A hush in the hallway, a soft, velvet blue.
Let not a whisper disturb the serene,
Nor shadows be troubled by what might have been.

The world in its quiet, a cradle of peace,
Where fears are forgotten and worries release.
Let the night sleep—let it dream as you do,
Of new dawns to come, of hope breaking through.

So close tired eyes, let your heart gently keep
This promise of stillness, this rare, precious deep.
Let the night sleep, for in darkness you’ll find
A gentle renewal, a rest for the mind.

Let the night sleep, as silence softly grows,
Velvet shadows gather where the tired river flows.
The clocks slow their ticking, the world holds its breath,
Wrapped in a promise of rest underneath.

Let the night sleep, no footsteps disturb
The hush of the moment, no reason to curb.
All worry and wonder drift far out of sight—
Let the night sleep, let the world set things right.

Trust in the darkness, its patient embrace,
Tomorrow waits gently, no need to chase.
Let the night sleep, let the stars gently weep,
For even the restless deserve time to sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
People long for shore, for settled sand—  
A place to rest, a gentle hand.  
Yet hope, that restless, flickering spark,  
Is found where roads are rough and dark.  

Stilled waters show no stars above;  
Still hearts forget the ache of love.  
But journeys call the soul to roam,  
To cast off comfort, far from home.  

In cracks of doubt, the green shoots grow;  
In winds of change, the dreamers know  
That only those who dare unrest  
May find the life that fits them best.  

So let the longing never cease—  
Let questions trouble simple peace.  
For in the yearning, hope is spun—  
The journey started, never done.

People wish for roots, a calm embrace,  
A plot of earth, a settled place.  
Yet hope is born when winds unsettle,  
When hearts are stirred, and doubts unsettle.  

To wish for peace is not a crime,  
But hope grows wild, not bound by time.  
In restless nights and shifting sand,  
We find new dreams, and understand.  

The soul that never knows unrest  
May never seek a higher quest.  
So let us wander, let us roam,  
Let hope disturb our sense of home.  

In being lost, we find the way—  
In tides of change, we learn to sway.  
For hope is found, not in the end,  
But in each bend where we transcend.

People yearn for comfort’s chain,  
A hearth, a roof against the rain.  
Yet hope flares brightest when we roam,  
When we have not yet found our home.  

The settled life can dim the fire,  
Quell the need to reach up higher.  
But in each tremor, in each doubt,  
A sprout of possibility breaks out.  

Let us not rush to anchor fast,  
Nor mourn the storms that will not pass.  
For it is in the open sea  
That hope compels us to be free.  

So may we cherish what’s unknown,  
Embrace the wind, the wild, the lone.  
For only when we’re unsettled, true,  
Does hope show all that we can do.

We seek a shore, a gentle land,  
A resting place, a guiding hand.  
Yet hope is found not where we sleep,  
But where the questions stir and seep.  

Within the storm, the heart reveals  
A longing for what change conceals.  
For settled souls may close the door  
On what the future holds in store.  

So let us walk on shifting ground,  
Embrace the not-yet, all around.  
For in the movement, hope is born—  
A promise carried, faint but warm.  

We settle only to be stirred;  
The truest hope is never cured.  
Unsettled hearts will dare to roam,  
And find, in wandering, a home.

People crave a settled place,  
A steady path, a tranquil space.  
Yet hope is restless as the sea—  
It grows where souls refuse to be.  

Unsettled hearts can dream and strive,  
To leap, to fall, to feel alive.  
The urge for more, the push to see,  
Is hope’s own wild alchemy.  

Let not the longing for the end  
Replace the will to break and bend.  
In every doubt, in every fear,  
A brighter future lingers near.  

So let us thank the storms we bear—  
The winds that toss us everywhere.  
For only when the soul’s unmet  
Is hope a fire burning yet.

So let us cherish, not condemn,

We dream of settling, of solid ground,

But hope is not in stillness found—

The heart that rests too long in ease

Unsettled souls, with eyes alight,

So let us bless the restless ways,

Settled hearts may wish for ease,

Unsettled souls, with restless feet,

In shifting sands, in winds that change,

So let us not lament the ache,

For hope is born in hearts that roam,

We crave the comfort of the known,

But hope, elusive as the dawn,
Comes only when we journey on.

To be unsettled is to breathe
The air of what might yet be wreathed
In possibility, untried—
A thousand roads we’ve not yet eyed.

The settled soul may yearn for rest,
Yet finds in stillness not its best.
For only in the questing mind
Does hope’s bright thread entwine and bind.

So let us welcome restless nights,
Unanswered questions, daring flights—
For hope lives where the heart’s unbound,
And dreams grow wild, not underground.

It’s born where hearts are questing, unsettled by despair.

A spark is in the wandering, the roads that twist and bend,
The questions ever-pondering, the dreams that have no end.
To settle is to slumber, to let the fire grow cold,
But hope lives in the thunder, in stories yet untold.

So may we stay unsettled, with minds alive and free,
For only in the wrestle is hope’s vitality.
We wish to be at anchor, but stars call us to roam,
For hope is in the journey—and never in the home.

We crave the quiet certainty of stone,
A hearth, a roof, a world we claim our own,
Yet hope is like a root that seeks the rain—
It grows, unsettled, through the cracks of pain.

In comfort’s clasp, our dreams may fall asleep,
But restless hearts sow futures we can reap.
The wish to settle whispers in our bones,
Yet only in the seeking are we known.

Let longing be the compass, not the chain,
Let questions lead us outward once again.
Unsettled, we are vessels for the light—
Each step in doubt, a step toward what is right.

So may we never settle, never cease,
In moving, find the hope that grants us peace.

People gather in search of calm,
Yearning for the tranquil balm
Of settled days and anchored hearts,
A place where every trouble parts.

But hope is restless, never tamed,
Born not where life is neatly framed,
But in the chaos, shifting sand,
Where dreams are drawn by daring hand.

The wish to settle, strong and deep,
Can lull the soul into a sleep;
Yet only when the heart’s unmoored
Can hopes unimagined be restored.

So chase the wind, embrace the change,
Let comfort’s borders rearrange.
For in the unsettlement we find
A hope that’s restless, undefined.

People wish for solid ground,
For lives that circle, safe and sound,
But hope is not a settled thing—
It lives where nerves and questions sting.

A river carves its hopeful path
Unsettled, free from aftermath.
The longing for a final home
Is what unsettles hearts to roam.

To settle is to end the tale,
To close the sails, to never fail—
But in the wind and rising foam,
Hope calls the wanderer to roam.

So let us cherish what we lack,
The open road, the untrod track.
For hope is found, where all is new—
Unsettled hearts, forever true.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
We crave the weight of certainty, a home built on stone—  
Walls that won’t tremble, a hearth that won’t chill.  
Yet hope arrives as a hush in the wind,  
Whispering us restless, never standing still.  

Let the dust rise where we walk,  
Let the unfamiliar beckon beyond the hill.  
For in every unsettled moment,  
A new world stirs, a dream is distilled.  

We wish for roots, deep and unmoving,  
But it’s in the wandering that we grow.  
Hope is the spark in uncertainty’s shadow,  
A lantern we carry wherever we go.

People wish to be settled, to nest in the gentle hush,  
But hope is an ember in the wind,  
Flaring bright when comfort’s rush  
Is traded for the unknown’s spin.  

Roots are tempting, promising peace,  
Yet it’s the uprooted heart that truly sings,  
For every longing for release  
Unfolds the sky on restless wings.  

Let us not lock the doors too soon—  
May uncertainty be our guiding moon.  
For in unsettlement, we dream and strive;  
Only then is hope alive.

To be settled is to rest in sunlight’s gentle palm,  
To close the shutters, let silence be balm.  
Yet, hope is a river that carves through stone,  
Restless and wild, alive and unknown.  

We tether ourselves to the promise of peace,  
But in the tremor, our longings increase.  
In every unanswered question, hope takes its breath;  
Only the unsettled can dream past death.  

So let the winds unsettle the dust,  
Let uncertainty teach us to trust.  
For as long as we wander, our hearts remain wide,  
Alive with the hope that unsettledness hides.

We yearn for stillness, for the anchor's weight—  
A home, a name, a path well-laid.  
Yet as we settle, hope slips through our hands,  
A wild bird startled from its plans.  

It is the unsettled soul that dares to dream,  
That finds new colors in the in-between.  
For only in motion, in longing and quest,  
Can hope take root and build its nest.  

Let us welcome the shifting, the unknown, the strange—  
To remain unsettled is to welcome change.  
In restless hearts, hope’s fire is fanned—  
And in unsettlement, we understand.

We build our houses out of certainty,  
Brick by brick, longing for rest.  
But as the mortar dries, our dreams grow thin,  
And hope slips quietly from the nest.  

Yet, when the winds unsettle the eaves,  
And the floor beneath us starts to shake,  
We find ourselves alive to possibility,  
Awake to the leaps we still can take.  

Let us cherish the trembling, the not-quite-known,  
For in that space, hope is sown.  
People wish to be settled, but in the drift,  
We find the gift.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love—
The moon a silent witness to the ache in my chest.
Each footstep echoes with memories we wove,
Soft laughter drifting on wind, moments blessed.

The world is hushed in the silver of night,
Yet your voice lingers, sweet and clear.
In shadows, I reach for you, holding you tight,
Though distance and darkness draw you near.

I wander beneath the trembling stars above,
Their light a gentle promise of what we knew—
When I walk alone, I think of you, my love,
And the path grows gentle, paved by dreams of you.

When I walk alone, I think of you, my love,
Beneath the tangled trees, beneath the wheeling dove.
The hush between my footsteps is filled with silent song,
A melody of longing for a place where I belong.

The breeze that stirs the willows whispers of your name,
And every passing shadow seems to burn with gentle flame.
Though distance lies between us, and the night is cold and deep,
Your memory walks beside me in the promises I keep.

So let the world be empty, and the road be dark and long—
For when I walk alone, I think of you, and I am strong.

When I walk alone, I think of you, my love;
The rustle of leaves reminds me of your laughter.
Each solitary step recalls the warmth of your touch,
And the quiet dusk holds echoes of our after.

The path ahead is empty, yet you fill every space—
A whisper of your name carried by the breeze.
I trace the lines of memory, the soft glow of your face,
Finding solace in longing, a heart put at ease.

With every stride, the distance shrinks between us,
Your presence lingers, gentle as a dove.
When I walk alone, I am not truly lonely—
For I walk with thoughts of you, my love.

When I walk alone, I think of you, my love,
A phantom touch upon my hand, the sigh
Of gentle winds that whisper from above,
And all the stars that scatter in the sky.

Your laughter lingers in the empty street,
A memory, soft as a faded song.
The world around is hushed, and bittersweet,
Yet in my heart your presence stays so strong.

Each step I take, though solitary, gleams
With echoes of the days we once both knew.
When I walk alone, I walk with dreams—
For in every silent moment, I find you.

When I walk alone, I think of you, my love.
The city lights blur softly, as if they, too, recall
the warmth of your hand, the hush of evening’s glove,
And the promise that tomorrow would not let us fall.

Each shadow on the pavement is a memory’s trace,
A fragment of laughter, a smile left behind.
I gather them gently, walking at my own pace,
Finding comfort in longing, solace in mind.

Though the night grows deeper, and the silence grows wide,
Your presence surrounds me, unseen but true.
When I walk alone, you are there at my side—
A gentle reminder: my heart walks with you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Footsteps echoing in the empty street.

A gentle breeze stirs petals by my side,

I follow where the silver moonbeams guide,
Recalling laughter in the afterglow.

Though solitude may wrap me in its arms,
Your presence lingers close, a phantom touch.
The world is brighter for your quiet charms,

Each silent moment, woven through and through,

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The silent city shimmers in the dusk.
Each lamp-lit window glows like stars above,
And every memory carries your warm musk.

The rustle of the leaves beneath my feet
Sings softly of the laughter that we shared.
The passing strangers, faces bittersweet,
Remind me how I wish that you were there.

Yet solitude is gentle when you’re near
In heart and thought, though far in time and space.
Your whispered name dispels the creeping fear,
And in the shadows, I still find your grace.

So as I wander, lost in starlit view,
My every step, my love, returns to you.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The fading light, the hush that evening brings.
Your memory, gentle as a mourning dove,
Follows me softly, fluttering its wings.

My shadow lengthens on the quiet road,
While thoughts of you are lanterns in the night.
A thousand dreams in silent rivers flowed,
All drift to you, my beacon and my light.

Though distance lies between each step I take,
Your laughter lingers like a summer breeze.
You are the dawn that breaks when I awake,

So as I wander, missing you anew,
Each step I take, I take in love with you.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
With every step, your memory grows near.
The sky above is vast and deep enough
To hold my longing, every hope and fear.

The city’s pulse is distant in my ear,
Yet in my chest, your heartbeat echoes still.
I feel your laughter scattered on the air,
Your gentle touch in every midnight chill.

I walk beneath the trembling autumn trees,
Remembering the warmth of your embrace.
Though solitude is carried on the breeze,
I find your shadow in each empty place.

So let me walk alone, but not apart—
For every path I take, you walk my heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter wild, their hands calloused, tough,
In smoky inns, with tankards raised high,
They sang of the soil and the wind-swept sky.

Yet in their hearts, a gentle flame burned,
For songs of love and dreams unreturned;
Through muddy fields and tempest's roar,
The poet's words made spirits soar.

He saw in them not brute nor beast,
But hunger for hope, for beauty at least.
In ale-stained rooms, with voices bold,
A softer truth in verses told.

So let us not scorn the simple crowd,
For in their roughness, Burns avowed,
There lies a kinship, strong and deep—
A poet’s promise, for all to keep.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter coarse, their speech enough
To split the air with tales of night,
Of muddy boots and fists that fight.

Yet in their eyes a spark did gleam,
A yearning for a gentler dream;
For songs that told of love and loss,
Of golden fields and morning’s gloss.

Their jests were loud, their tempers keen,
Their hearts, though hidden, oft unseen.
But Burns, he saw the soul beneath—
The fragile hope, the quiet grief.

So let us toast the bard who found
A melody in common ground,
For through his verse, both rough and mild,
He named the man within the wild.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With weathered hands and faces tough,
In smoky taverns, loud and bright,
They drank and sang into the night.

Their laughter echoed, raw and free,
Yet Burns, he saw what few could see:
A longing soul beneath the skin,
A tenderness that dwelled within.

These men of earth, of sweat and toil,
Who wrestled life from stubborn soil,
Found in his verse a fleeting grace,
A mirror for the common face.

So let us raise a glass to those
Whose rugged hearts the poet chose,
For poetry, like Burns, reveals
The roughest man still loves and feels.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter brash, their language gruff,
Yet in their eyes a glimmer shone,
A longing for a world unknown.

In smoky pubs, they'd gather near,
To share a song, a tale, a beer,
And though their days were harsh and long,
They found some solace in a song.

For Burns, he saw the heart beneath,
The hidden hope, the quiet grief;
He penned their dreams, their loves, their pain,
And gave them voice in sweet refrain.

So let us not dismiss the crowd
Whose voices rise both coarse and loud,
For Burns, the bard, knew well enough:
There's beauty in the rude and rough.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their faces lined, their voices gruff,
Yet from their lips the verses spilled
Of love and loss, of dreams fulfilled.

In smoky taverns, crowded, loud,
They toasted life, a rowdy crowd,
But in their songs, a gentler tone,
A longing for a life unknown.

For Burns, he saw beyond the skin,
The tenderness that lay within.
His words, a bridge from man to man,
Revealed the soul where hope began.

So let us praise the poet's art,
That found the beauty in each heart,
And know, through Burns, we understand
The roughest men have gentle hands.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair,
Let sorrow tie my hands with thread,
When morning light, so soft and fair,
Calls hope to rise from where I bled?

The world may turn with weary sighs,
And shadows press upon my chest,
Yet in the hush of midnight skies,
A gentle promise bids me rest.

For every dream that slipped away,
A newer song awaits the dawn;
Despair may whisper me to stay,
But I must rise and journey on.

So let not grief consume the day,
Nor bind my heart with silent care;
For in the sun’s forgiving ray,
I’ll find my peace beyond despair.

Shall I, wasting in despair,
Let time erode the hope I bear?
Or rise anew with every dawn,
And find the strength to carry on?

The bitter winds of doubt may blow,
And shadows stretch where I must go,
Yet still my spirit, tired but true,
Will seek the light that breaks the blue.

Despair may tempt with velvet chains,
But freedom sings within my veins.
So I will stand and face the storm,
And from my trials, courage form.

For in the ashes, seeds are sown—
A garden born of tears I've known.
Shall I, wasting in despair?
No. I will choose the morning air.

Shall I, wasting in despair,
Let sorrow claim my gentle heart?
Or find within the midnight air
A spark, a flame, a new fresh start?

The moon will wax, the tides will turn,
And time will heal the wounds I bear;
So let me from this moment learn
That hope still glimmers through despair.

Though shadows stretch along my way,
And silent tears may fall unseen,
I’ll rise to greet the breaking day
And walk where softer steps have been.

So no, I shall not waste nor weep
For dreams that faded in the night;
But gather what I wish to keep
And step again into the light.

Shall I, wasting in despair,
Let my soul dissolve in air,
Tethered by a thread of doubt,
Afraid to let the sunlight out?

No, I will not yield to night,
Nor let my heart forget the light.
Though sorrow's hands may touch my face,
I find within a quiet grace.

Petals fall, but roots remain,
Life returns with gentle rain.
Broken dreams may line the floor,
Yet hope will always build a door.

So shall I waste in sorrow’s snare?
Or rise, release the aching care?
I’ll gather strength from whispered prayer,
And claim the dawn beyond despair.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Letting all my colors fade?
Or reach for hope that’s always there,
A gentle hand in darkest shade?

The night may press with heavy gloom,
And tears may fall like silver rain;
Yet dawn ignites the silent room,
And softly soothes the sharpest pain.

I will not let my spirit tire,
Nor let regret become my song.
For deep within, a quiet fire
Insists the world still moves along.

So, shall I wasting in despair?
No—I'll rise and breathe the air.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text: Shall I wasting in despair, / Let sorrow claim my days? / No, I will gather morning air, / And walk in golden rays. // Though shadows stretch across the field, / And tears may stain the night, / I’ll let my wounded spirit yield / To hope’s returning light. // For love may bruise and longing ache, / And dreams may slip away, / Yet every dawn bids hearts awake, / To find a gentler way. // So I will not in sorrow dwell, / Nor let my spirit break, / For life has sweeter tales to tell / With each new breath I take.

Shall I wasting in despair / Watch the slow hours drift and fade? / Night falls heavy on the air, / My hopes in shadows laid. // Yet in the silence, soft and deep, / A trembling spark remains— / Whispering dreams I long to keep / Through heartache’s gentle rains. // Time may steal the morning’s song, / And sorrow cloud the sky, / But I will not, for all that’s wrong, / Let love’s bright promise die. // For in the ashes of regret, / New seeds of joy take root— / Shall I wasting in despair forget / The sun, the stars, the truth?

Shall I wasting in despair, / Drown in sorrow’s endless tide? / Or rise and banish every care, / Let hope and faith abide? // The night may whisper bitter things, / And heartache cloud my view, / Yet morning breaks on golden wings, / And paints the world anew. // I will not yield to hopelessness, / Nor let my spirit fade; / For every wound and emptiness, / A brighter path is laid. // So let me gather strength again, / And greet the coming day, / Refusing grief, defying pain, / I’ll find my own sweet way.

Shall I wasting in despair / Sit silent in my grief? / Or seek the sunlight in the air, / And find in hope relief? // The world is wide and full of song, / Though sorrow dims the tune; / The night is never dark for long, / It yields to brighter noon. // With every tear a lesson grows, / With every ache a flame; / New petals bloom from winter’s snows, / New joys call out my name. // So I will rise from where I fell, / And lift my eyes above— / For life is more than tears that swell, / It’s also dreams and love.

Shall I wasting in despair / Let longing be my only friend? / Or trust that wounds begin to wear, / And broken hearts will mend? // I’ve wandered through the silent years / With shadows in my mind, / Yet every storm dissolves in tears / And leaves some peace behind. // The world will turn, the morning break, / The sun will rise anew; / And even when my spirits ache, / I’ll find the strength to move. // So let me not in sorrow stay, / Nor wish for what has passed— / I’ll greet the promise of today, / And let the darkness last.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair,
Counting hours in silent gloom?
Shall I tend the empty air
And water shadows as they bloom?

No! Let the daylight find me bold,
Heart unshackled, eyes aware;
For what is love, if bought or sold,
But wind that tangles in my hair?

Let not my spirit break and fall,
Nor wilt beneath a lover’s snare.
I’ll gather joy where wild birds call—
I shall not wasting in despair.

Though sorrow stirs the midnight sea,
And hope seems fragile, slight, and rare,
Still, I will keep my soul with me—
And not go wasting in despair.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Drifting through a world unkind?
Shall I let the hollow air
Echo burdens of the mind?

No, I’ll rise with every dawn,
Brush the shadows from my heart,
Trust the pain will soon be gone,
And each new day a gentle start.

Though love may come, and love may go,
Leaving sorrow, dust, and pain,
I’ll not let despairing grow
Where hope and promise still remain.

So, I’ll stand and face the sky,
Breathing deep the morning air;
I will not, I shall not lie—
Wasting, wasting in despair.

Shall I wasting in despair
For love that will not see?
Shall I count each silent prayer,
And mourn what cannot be?

The night is deep and cold,
Yet hope flickers in the dark.
If stories are retold,
Perhaps there still remains a spark.

Let not the weeping hours claim
My soul with endless care;
Though love may never speak my name,
I will not waste in despair.

With dawn, I rise anew,
My heart a page, unwritten, fair—
The world is wide, the sky is blue;
I shall not wasting in despair.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Letting sorrow claim the day?
Or shall I lift my head and dare
To chase the clouds away?

The world turns on, indifferent, sure,
Yet every breath is fresh and free.
Why linger long where wounds endure,
When hope still calls to me?

Though love may fade, though dreams depart,
And shadows gather everywhere,
I’ll mend the rifts within my heart—
I shall not wasting in despair.

For life’s too brief for endless tears,
Too swift for burdens hard to bear;
I’ll gather strength from passing years,
And rise, unbowed, from my despair.

Shall I wasting in despair,
For what was never truly mine?
Shall I fret and linger there,
Where old regrets and sorrows twine?

No, let me walk the winding road,
With hope to light each hour.
Let my spirit bear its load,
And gather grace from every flower.

For love, though sweet, is not my all,
Nor loss the end of every care.
Let me rise when shadows fall—
I shall not wasting in despair.

The world is vast, the sky is wide,
New joys await me unaware;
So onward now, with steady stride,
I will not wasting in despair.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:

No, though sorrow marks my days,

Shall I wasting in despair,
Or choose to rise, and meet the air?

Though the hours pass me by,

For each sorrow, hope is sown—

Must I yield to bitter air,

Yet the dawn, with gentle hand,

Though the night be long and deep,

No, I’ll seek the morning’s fire,

Grief may press its cold embrace,

For in the quiet, hope awakes,
Gently urging what it takes,
To lift my gaze, to breathe the air—
Shall I wasting in despair?

No, I’ll find the dawn’s release,
And let my troubled heart find peace.

The morning sun will rise anew,

Though despair may call my soul,

Shall I wasting in despair
Count each sorrow, one by one?
The hours drift heavy in the air,

Yet while the river mourns its way

A distant bird begins to play—
A song to soften, if not stall.

I gather broken hopes like thread,
Weave them gently, line by line.
Shall I waste, or rise instead—

Despair may call me to remain,

Shall I wasting in despair,
Let love’s bright embers fade to dust?
Or shall I, with courage rare,

The night may stretch in endless grey,
Regrets may haunt my every breath,
But dawn will break with gentle sway,
And life will triumph over death.

For every sorrow, there is song,
For every loss, a seed is sown.
Though shadows linger, not for long—
The heart will learn to walk alone.

So shall I waste or shall I strive?
In choosing hope, I stay alive.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Let my spirit fade away?
Or will I rise from heavy care,
And greet the promise of the day?

The night is long, the silence deep,
And doubt creeps cold across my chest.
Yet dawn will rouse me from my sleep,
And urge my heart to seek its rest.

For every sorrow, time will mend;
For every tear, a seed is sown.
Despair may linger, yet its end
Is but the start of hope I’ve known.

So shall I waste, or shall I rise?
I’ll choose the sun, forsake the sighs.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, the shadows softly crept,
A gentle hush across the starlit floor.
The world outside, a memory I kept,
As dream-wings carried me to distant shores.

In twilight’s hush, my worries slipped away,
The moonlight weaving silver in my hair.
A lullaby of distant yesterday
Played softly on the cool and fragrant air.

The night embraced me, silent and complete,
With velvet arms that promised gentle peace.
In my first sleep, the world was bittersweet,
And time itself, for one bright moment, ceased.

When morning woke, the dawn was pale and deep;
I longed to wander back to my first sleep.

In my first sleep, the world was hushed and kind,
A cradle rocked by whispers of the night.
No memory to burden heart or mind,
Just shadows dancing softly out of sight.

I drifted far on currents cool and deep,
Beneath the surface, ancient voices sang.
The hush of stars around me in my sleep,
The distant chime where silver echoes rang.

I did not know the edges of my form,
Nor where the dream began and waking fled.
The dark was not a danger, but a warm,
Embracing place where gentle visions led.

In my first sleep, I traveled far and wide,
And woke with wonder softly at my side.

In my first sleep, the silence wore a crown—
A hush of velvet, deep against my skin.
The world outside dissolved, and settled down
Into a sea where gentle tides begin.

My thoughts grew light as dandelion seeds,
Drifting beyond the reach of waking care.
A quiet kingdom, built on secret needs,
Opened its gates and beckoned me in there.

No memory yet troubled calm repose,
No echo of the sun’s relentless climb;
Just darkness, soft as petals, gently grows
To cradle me outside the bounds of time.

In my first sleep, I learned to trust the deep—
To dream, to drift, and softly, sweetly sleep.

In my first sleep, the world was still,
A hush upon the window sill.
The gentle dark, the silent air,
A cradle rocking everywhere.

I wandered softly, unafraid,
In dreamscapes memory never made.
The breath of night, a whispered tune,
Beneath a watchful, distant moon.

No worries yet had found my mind,
No sorrow, loss, nor ties that bind.
Only the wonder, fresh and deep,
Of secret places first in sleep.

And when the dawn in gold did creep,
I sighed and left my first, sweet sleep.

In my first sleep, the night was velvet-dark,
A gentle hush upon my brow was laid.
Soft echoes drifted, quiet as a lark,
Through silent rooms where golden shadows played.

I wandered there, in innocence and peace,
A drifting leaf on currents slow and deep.
The world, unformed, was eager to release
Its stories whispered only in my sleep.

No burden yet, no memory to keep,
Just promise in the hush of midnight’s air.
The dreams I gathered, fragile, bright, and steep,
Would vanish with the dawn, but linger there.

In my first sleep, I learned the shape of night—
A gentle hand that led me toward the light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Its silver sinew cleaves the night in two,
A whistle trailing echoes, faint and starting,
Moonlit fields recede in misty blue.

Carriages cradle dreamers, softly swaying,
Windows flicker, lanterned with stories told,
Steel on steel, the world outside delaying,
Inside, hearts gather memories to hold.

Through forest shadows, riverbanks unbending,
Past silent towns and stations lost to time,
The engine's pulse is constant, never ending,
Its longing song a wordless, distant rhyme.

Like an arrow, hope and yearning intertwine,
The train is darting—onward, down the line.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Its breath a cloud upon the midnight air.
The rails awake with silver sparks, imparting
A rhythm to the silence, sharp and rare.

Each window frames a fleeting constellation,
Passengers adrift in distant dreams.
The engine’s heart beats with anticipation,
Chasing dawn along the river’s seams.

The world recedes, a blur of sleeping houses,
Fields asleep beneath the velvet dome.
The train, undaunted, through the darkness rouses,
Bearing all its secrets safely home.

Like a promise in the night, the journey started:
A long arrow through the dark, the train is darting.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Thunder on the tracks, a flash of steel and spark.
Beneath the sleeping towns, the midnight shadows parting,
Hushed faces lit by lamps, adrift within the dark.

The engine’s distant heartbeat echoes through the hollow,
Wheels drum an ancient song against the iron rails.
Dreamers clutching tickets, their hopes and worries follow,
While moonlight stains the windows with ephemeral veils.

Onward, ever onward, past rivers, woods, and meadows,
The train slices through silence, relentless and unseen.
Night’s velvet folds unravel in its fleeting shadows,
A long arrow through the dark—the path where dreams convene.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Splitting silence with its purposeful cry,
Steel and shadow, hope and memory charting
A path through the hush where old stations lie.

In the windows, faces flicker and vanish,
Lit by the ghost of a passing town’s gleam,
Each heart tethered to wishes it cannot banish,
Carried onward in the slipstream of dream.

The world outside is a blur of night’s longing,
Fields and forests swallowed in the black,
Yet the train, unyielding, keeps forging and thronging

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side—  
They slip quietly, longing for gravity's embrace,  
Abandoning the shelter of my hollowed cheeks,  
Leaving salt stains trailing down an empty place.  

Even grief deserts me, a guest who will not tarry,  
My sorrow is a bird uncaged, fleeing dusk's blue tide.  
I reach for solace, but it whispers away,  
I am left with absence, my ache unoccupied.  

Memories falter, shadows scatter on the floor,  
Each drop a fragment of what I tried to hide.  
How strange to mourn with nothing left to hold,  
To weep for comfort, yet find it denied.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  
They vanish like ghosts at the edge of the dawn,  
Leaving no trace on my cheeks or my pillow,  
No witness to sorrow, no evidence drawn.  

I reach for the comfort I once found in rain,  
But the storm passes through me, unfeeling, untried.  
My sadness is silent, invisible pain—  
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  

Maybe one day they’ll return, gentle and slow,  
To water the seeds of the hurt I confide,  
But tonight I am empty, with nothing to show:  
I cry, and the tears don’t even stay by my side.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  
They tumble and fall, racing away from my face—  
A silent betrayal, a shimmering tide,  
Escaping my sorrow with effortless grace.  

I reach for the comfort of lingering pain,  
But droplets desert me, they’re gone with the rain.  
Loneliness laughs in the hollow they leave,  
A hush in the darkness that I cannot grieve.  

How strange that my sadness, so heavy and deep,  
Is carried away on the wings of a stream,  
And left on my skin only memories seep—  
I cry, and my tears disappear in a dream.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side—  
They slip away quickly, as if they are shy,  
Leaving my sorrow exposed in the night,  
A river that runs where no comfort is nigh.  

I reach for each droplet, but they do not linger,  
Sliding away from the warmth of my skin.  
I wonder if sadness is lighter than water,  
Or if grief is a current that pulls from within.  

Still, I search for a solace that never arrives,  
A touch that might anchor my pain,  
But the tears don’t remain, they leave me behind,  
Alone with the ache and the stain.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  
They flee, unruly, from the corners of my eyes,  
As if my sadness repels them, as if they, too,  
Would rather not linger where sorrow lies.  

I watch them abandon me, silver trails fading,  
And wonder if grief is meant to be shared,  
Or if even my tears find my ache too parading,  
And choose to fall elsewhere, unprepared.  

Perhaps they seek solace in the earth below,  
Or join with the rain in a sorrowful tide.  
But I am left empty, bereft and alone—  
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A tapestry of dreams unfurled;
Moonlight gathers at her head,
A silver veil on shadowed world.

The clock’s soft ticking marks the space
Between each hope and memory,
While gentle night, with quiet grace,
Spins solace through uncertainty.

She listens close to distant sounds—
A whisper in the sleeping air;
Her thoughts, like stars, make secret rounds,
Illuminating what’s not there.

Yet in the hush, her spirit grows,
Unraveling the silent thread;
A strength within the darkness glows,
Though she lies alone upon her bed.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Curtains drawn against the night,
A thousand words remain unsaid,
Soft shadows dancing in the light.

Her thoughts drift out on silent seas,
To places only she can find,
Each memory a gentle breeze
That stirs the corners of her mind.

Her hands are folded on her chest,
Her breathing slow, a whispered prayer,
The world outside, a distant guest,
Unknowing of her longing there.

Yet in the quiet, hope is spun,
A golden thread through dreams she weaves;
Until the darkness comes undone,
And morning sunlight gently cleaves.

She lies alone upon her bed,
With moonlight tangled in her hair.
The gentle hush of midnight spreads
A velvet silence through the air.

Her thoughts are distant, drifting slow,
A river winding through her chest,
She wonders where the lost dreams go,
And if her heart will find its rest.

The world outside grows still and deep,
A cradle rocked by unseen hands;
She closes eyes and slips to sleep,
Adrift in far and silent lands.

She lies alone upon her bed,
The sheets a field of white embrace,
Her thoughts like petals softly shed,
A memory in empty space.

The shadows gather round her form,
A gentle cloak for sleepless eyes,
She listens to the distant storm
And wonders if the dawn will rise.

Yet in the quiet, hope remains,
A fragile bloom within her chest,
Though solitude and silence reign,
Her heart endures, her soul finds rest.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A whisper caught in tangled sheets,
The lamp beside her burns a thread
Of golden light that softly greets.

Her window opens to the stars,

She counts the moments, near and far,
And gathers comfort from the calm.

Sleep tiptoes close, but will not stay,
Her mind a maze of hopes and fears.
She waits for morning’s gentle sway,
To dry the salt of midnight’s tears.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Through shadowed gates, the mourners tread,
A city veiled in silent lament,
Where sorrow’s river softly spread.

The stones remember every sigh,
Each echo weaves a tapestry of pain,
And pale, reluctant dawns drift by,
Touched by an unrelenting rain.

Here, memories flicker in twilight air,
Footsteps vanish on ashen streets,
Yet hope, a fragile, flickering prayer,
Persists where every sorrow meets.

So, through these gates, I journey slow—

Bearing the weight of what they know,
Beneath a sky forever clouded.

Per me si va nella citta dolente,
Into the city of sorrow I tread,
Where shadows coil in alleys bent,
And silence cloaks the words unsaid.

Stone bridges arch above regret,
Their arches heavy with remorse,
Lanterns flicker, pale and set,
Guiding souls along their course.

Here, every echo is a sigh,
Each window weeps with unseen tears,
Yet still, I walk, compelled to try
To pierce the shroud of ancient fears.

O city of dolor, I enter your gates,
Carrying hope that sorrow abates.

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Through me, you enter the grieving city,
Where silent arches and sunless stone
Bear witness to humanity’s pity.

Shadows linger in every street,
And every breath is a whispered prayer,
Yet something gentle moves beneath—
A pulse of love in the heavy air.

Here, the hearts are heavy and old,
But not without the will to dream;
A city of sorrow, a tale retold,
Where light can still be seen to gleam.

I walk these roads with open eyes,
And leave with hope that never dies.

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Beyond this gate, the aching city sighs.
Marble angels watch with hollow eyes
As dusk unfurls its sorrow in the streets.

Here, footsteps echo stories left unsaid,
And every shadow knows a lover’s loss.
The wind unravels secrets of the dead,
Carrying memories across the moss.

Yet in the hush between the tolling bells,
A silver thread of yearning weaves through pain.
Even where despair and silence dwells,
A fragile hope endures, not lost in vain.

So let me enter, heart both numb and bold—
To find the song that sorrow never told.

Per me si va nella citta dolente,
Here, the gates swing wide to grief’s domain,
Where every stone remembers lament,
And every street is heavy with pain.

Beneath pale lamps, the shadows sigh,
Their silent chorus fills the air.
No laughter climbs to meet the sky—
Only the hush of muted prayer.

Yet, walking through this mournful place,
A gentle candle flickers bright;

So, through these gates I enter slow,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Homer poured, in thousand wrote.'

responses.text:
Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Verses vast as seas afloat,
Sung from lips of ancient fire,
Kindling hearts with old desire.

He set the oar, he turned the sail,
Mapped the storm and told the tale,
Echoed thunder, conjured light,
In the ink of endless night.

Each syllable a briny wave,
Each image carved upon a cave,
His thousand words, a single song,
Echoing where dreams belong.

Still we hear those distant oars,
Still we haunt those mythic shores;
For every line the poet wrote,
A world awoke, a hero spoke.

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
A sea of stories, line by line,
Odysseys in every note,
Heroes lost to myth and time.

His ink became the surging tide,
Of gods and mortals, fate entwined,
Where ancient voices still reside,
Within the labyrinth of the mind.

From wine-dark waves to burning Troy,
His words have traveled centuries,
A gift, a curse, a fragile joy—
The legacy of memories.

So let us drink from Homer’s well,
Of legends hewn in fire and dust,
And in his thousand lines we dwell,
In wonder, reverence, awe, and trust.

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
The wine of words, the song afloat.
A tapestry of gods and men,
Woven time and time again.

His syllables became the sea,
Where Odysseus longed to be;
Each line a wave upon the shore,
Each stanza opening a door.

Through burning Troy and storm-tossed foam,
His verses found their wanderer home.
In every echo, every note—
Homer poured, in thousand wrote.

So we, who read these ancient lines,
Are swept along by myth that shines;
The world reborn in every quote—
A thousand dreams, in thousand wrote.

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
His ink the river, myths the boat.
He ferried heroes, grief and pride,
On parchment waves, with gods beside.

A thousand lines, a thousand flames,
Echoed in our modern names.
From Ilium's fire to Ithaca’s shore,
His stories pulse forevermore.

The blind bard’s voice, a beacon bright,
Guides us through the epic night.
In every verse a truth is caught—
A lesson lived, a battle fought.

So let us gather round and note:
From Homer’s heart, the ages float.
In thousand wrote, in thousand read,
His ancient music never dead.

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
A river swelling with each note,
Stories spilled from lips of flame,
Echoes no time could ever tame.

He charted seas of endless blue,
Where gods and mortals drifted through,
And every line a tapestry,
Of longing, fate, and mystery.

Still, in quiet rooms we read,
The wine-dark words, the ancient creed,
And marvel at the worlds he spun,
The thousand tales, the ageless sun.

So let us listen, hearts remote,
To what the old blind poet wrote:
For in each verse, the ages float—
Homer poured, in thousand wrote.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

responses.text:
In Iliad’s heart, the tide of war turns red,
Patroclus, armored in Achilles’ stead,
Rages through Trojans, hope ignites anew,
Yet fate’s long shadow falls, as all men knew.

Apollo strikes, and armor’s borrowed pride
Cannot withstand the spear on Hector’s side.
The Greeks lament, Achilles’ wrath reborn,
Grief hardens in him, blinding and forlorn.

Hephaestus shapes new arms of star-bright fire,
A shield that holds the world, the gods’ desire,
Each ring and figure glimmers with the cost—
That even heroes, loved by gods, are lost.

So books sixteen through nineteen, sorrow’s seam,
Spin out the grief that underpins the dream:
The rage of men, the gods’ capricious hand,
The iron laws no mortal may withstand.

From book sixteen, Patroclus dons the guise,
Achilles’ armor shining in his eyes.
Into the fray he storms, a lion bold,
With hopes that Troy’s high gates at last unfold.

But fate is cruel, and Hector’s spear is true—
Patroclus falls, his borrowed glory through.
A friend’s death kindles anger, black as night;
Achilles rises, flaming with his might.

Hephaestus bends to forge the hero’s shield,
A world of wonders on its face revealed.
Achilles dons his armor, godly bright,
Prepared to hurl his fury in the fight.

Books sixteen to nineteen, sorrow’s song,
Where friendship, wrath, and destiny belong.
The tale of grief and vengeance, woven tight—
A tapestry of mortals, gods, and night.

An account of Iliad’s midmost tide:
Patroclus begs, Achilles’ rage denied,
To wear his armor, quell Troy’s blinding fire,
Hoping his borrowed form might yet inspire.

He charges forth, a comet blazing bright,
And Greeks exult beneath his borrowed light.
But fates converge—Apollo strikes him down,
Then Hector’s spear completes the laurel’s crown.

Achilles hears, his sorrow breaks the sky,
Hephaestus forges arms as gods stand by.
A shield whose circles hold the world entire,
Prepared for vengeance, death, and funeral pyre.

From sixteen through nineteen, Homer weaves
A tapestry of rage, of loss, of leaves
That fall too soon, of men and gods at war—
Of friendship’s end, and grief that knows no shore.

Books sixteen through nineteen, a storm of fate—
Patroclus pleads, and dons Achilles’ weight,
The Greek lines falter, hope ignites anew,
As Hector’s shadow grows within the dew.

He fights with fury, gods watch from above,
Patroclus falls, the price of borrowed love.
Achilles hears, and grief’s unending cry
Rends through the camp, a wrath none can deny.

Hephaestus shapes new armor, bright as stars,
A world’s reflection hammered into scars.
Achilles, armored, rises with the dawn,
To meet his destiny, his friend now gone.

Oh, these four books—a symphony of loss,
Of friendship, rage, and sacrifice, their cost.
The Iliad’s heart, where mortals’ tempests meet,
And sorrow, like the sea, is dark and deep.

In Homer’s telling, books sixteen to nineteen,
Mark the turning, the loss not yet foreseen.
Patroclus, eager, dons Achilles’ gear,
To save the Greeks, he casts aside his fear.

With borrowed might, he drives the Trojans back,
Yet hubris calls, and Hector finds his track.
Apollo’s hand, a shadow on the plain,
Patroclus falls, and grief becomes a chain.

Achilles’ wrath ignites, his sorrow vast,
No comfort soothes, his time of peace is past.
Hephaestus crafts new armor for the fight,
A cosmic shield to blaze against the night.

Thus, Iliad’s heart is wrenched with pain,
Love, loss, and vengeance mingling in the rain.
Through grief and rage, the poem’s arc is bent—
The gods look on, and mortals must lament.

Books sixteen through nineteen, burning flame.

The dust whirls up as horses scream and die,

With dying breath, the friend foretells the close:
That Hector falls, and Troy’s long torment grows.

Achilles’ grief: a flame that knows no rest,
He mourns his friend, his armor, and his quest.
The gods are watching, distant, cold, and vast—
In books sixteen through nineteen, fates are cast.

An account of books sixteen through nineteen—
Where valor’s cry and fate’s design convene—
The Iliad’s heart exposed upon the field,
In bronze and blood, where ancient furies yield.

Patroclus dons Achilles’ shining mail,
His borrowed glory ringing in the gale.
He leads the Myrmidons to war’s embrace,
A shadowed echo of his master’s face.

The Scamander runs red beneath the sun,
As Hector stalks; Apollo’s will is done.
Patroclus falls, a prophecy fulfilled—
And with his death, Achilles’ wrath is stilled.

But only briefly. Grief becomes a spear—
The son of Thetis rises, godlings near.
He slays in sorrow, strips his enemies,
And drags dear Hector’s body through the breeze.

Within these books, the tragedy is clear:
The cost of glory paid in mortal fear.

In books sixteen to nineteen, rage unfurls—
The cost of pride, the fate of mortal men.
Patroclus, clad in borrowed armor, hurls
Himself at Troy—Achilles’ wrath, again
Rekindled by the death of dearest friend.

The gods, capricious, meddle in the fray—
Apollo, Hector, all their fates entwined.
The shield of Hephaestus, bright as day,
Forged for the son of Thetis, soon aligned
With destiny. The Scamander runs with blood,
The towers echo with the weeping cries
Of those who mourn, as thunderheads and flood
Bear witness to the fall of hope and lies.

So through these books, the Iliad’s heart is shown:
Grief, vengeance, and the gods upon their throne.

An account of books sixteen through nineteen:
Patroclus dons Achilles’ shining gear,
His borrowed valor bright, his heart unseen,
He leads the Myrmidons in battle, near
To Troy’s high walls, where Hector’s shadow looms.
The dust is thick, the air alive with cries—
Bronze flashes, chariots in smoky plumes,
The gods descend with secrets and with lies.

Patroclus falls by Hector’s deadly hand,
A prophecy begun, a fury stirred.
The son of Peleus, wild, cannot withstand
His grief—a flame the winds of battle spurred.

Hephaestus at his forge prepares the shield,
A world of sorrow hammered in the gold.
Achilles rises, fate cannot be healed;
The tale of rage and loss again is told.

In the shadow of Troy’s battered walls, the tale darkens—
Book sixteen: Patroclus, desperate for glory and love,
Borrows Achilles’ armor and fate. Myrmidons thunder,
The Trojans scatter, but doom’s whisper grows.

Book seventeen: The death of Patroclus, his armor stripped,
Hector ascendant. Around the corpse, the battle rages,
Spears and grief interwoven, gods bickering above.

Book eighteen: Achilles learns the cost of pride, his rage
Twisting into sorrow. Hephaestus forges new armor,
A shield bright as memory, heavy as loss.

Book nineteen: Achilles returns to war, reconciled with Agamemnon,
But never again with peace. Blood and prophecy stain the sand,
And friendship is paid for in tears and flame.

So Homer sings—a dirge of wrath and ruin,
Where men are fleeting, and the gods watch on, amused,
In the bitter dawn of Ilium.

Sing, Muse, of sorrow on Scamander’s shore,
When Patroclus, armored in borrowed pride,

O Iliad, from ancient lips you tell:
Of love and loss, and men who fight and fell.

Upon the plain where fate and fury blend,
Patroclus, shielded in Achilles’ name,
Leads forth the Greeks, the gods his course attend,

From ships aflame to river’s swelling wrath,

Yet doom pursues along the bloodied path,
And Achilles’ grief becomes the battle’s wheel.

Friends fall, and heroes mourn with wailing loud,
Armor exchanged, but destinies remain,
The pyre burns bright, Achilles stands unbowed,
His vengeance looming over Troy’s domain.

So run the tales in Homer’s measured song:
Where love and anger drive the war along.

O Muse, recall the chapters steeped in night,
Where Patroclus, in Achilles’ shining shell,
Swept forth, a falcon in the thick of fight,
And fell, as gods and furies toll the knell.

The ships, alight with flame and mortal cries,
The river churns with blood and bronze and tears.
Achilles’ wrath, at last, unshackled, flies,
A storm to shake the city’s walls with fears.

Book after book, the poet’s voice resounds:
A funeral feast, a horse’s final race,
The cost of pride, the agony that hounds
Each hero’s step upon that ancient place.

Remember, then, the Iliad’s mournful sweep—
Of love and loss and vengeance buried deep.

Patroclus, clad in borrowed might, storms forth to leave a mark,

Yet doom lies in waiting, and nothing stays the hand of fate again.

The gods above conspire, rivers choke with blood,
The Myrmidons cry vengeance, grief flows as a flood.
Achilles, woken from his sorrow, hears his comrade’s dying word,
And from his rage, the war’s great thunder is stirred.

The rivers rage and gods descend, the earth shakes in despair,
For even mighty heroes bear burdens hard to bear.
Through Iliad’s heavy silence, in the shadow of Troy’s wall,
Echo the cost of valor and the price paid by all.

An account of books sixteen through nineteen:
The armor of Achilles gleams on another’s breast,
Patroclus rides to war, hope’s fragile sheen,
While gods debate, and mortals do their best.

The dust swirls thick, the spears fly fast,
Patroclus, bold, drives Trojans to their gates,
But fate and Apollo conspire at last,
And death in Hector’s shadow patiently waits.

The news strikes Achilles, a thunderous blow,
He rises in wrath, in sorrow, in flame,
The river boils, the gods descend below,
And vengeance becomes the only name.

So sing of loss, of fury, and of pain,
Of Iliad’s heart, and the blood-red plain.

Between the lines of Iliad, sixteen to nineteen,
The tides of war and destiny convene.
Patroclus dons the armor of his friend,
And to the field his borrowed light does send.

His valor stirs the Greeks, the Trojans reel,
Yet gods, unseen, their secret threads reveal.
Apollo strikes, and Hector’s spear finds home—
Patroclus falls, his spirit doomed to roam.

Achilles hears the news, his heart undone,
A sorrow deep as darkness without sun.
He rises, rage and mourning intertwined,
To seek revenge and leave all mercy blind.

These books recount the price of borrowed pride,
The tears of heroes, and the fates defied.
